papers.title: A Millimeter-Wave Superconducting Qubit
papers.relevance: Directly about superconducting qubits - presents a 72 GHz superconducting qubit operating at 0.9 K, with T1 and T2 times around 15 ns and quality factor Q ~ 7e3

summary: This blog post contains one paper directly about superconducting qubits. The paper 'A Millimeter-Wave Superconducting Qubit' (Anferov2024) describes a superconducting qubit operating at millimeter-wave frequencies (72 GHz) that can achieve >90% ground state population at 0.9 K refrigerator temperature, potentially eliminating the need for dilution refrigerators. The qubit has T1 and T2 coherence times of approximately 15 ns with a quality factor of Q ~ 7e3.

papers.title: How to Build a Quantum Supercomputer: Scaling Challenges and Opportunities
papers.relevance: Directly discusses superconducting qubit scaling, including wafer-scale fabrication (20k SC qubits per 12in wafer), cryostat wiring costs, and dilution refrigerator floorplanning for quantum supercomputers

summary: This blog post contains one paper directly relevant to superconducting circuits and qubits. The Mohseni2024 paper discusses scaling challenges for building quantum supercomputers, specifically addressing superconducting qubit fabrication at wafer scale (20k SC qubits per 12-inch wafer), cryogenic wiring costs ($4M of $5M cryostat budget), and dilution refrigerator cluster floorplanning. The blog post also mentions general quantum computing topics but does not contain other papers specifically about superconducting circuit physics, qubit coherence, Josephson junctions, or circuit QED implementations.

papers.title: Deterministic multi-phonon entanglement between two mechanical resonators on separate substrates

This paper is directly relevant to superconducting quantum circuits as it deals with mechanical resonators used in superconducting qubit systems. The blog post also includes general discussions about quantum computing roadmaps from Google and IBM (item #9), but these are not research papers about superconducting circuits.

This is directly relevant to superconducting qubit technology as capacitors are essential components in superconducting qubit architectures (e.g., transmons, fluxoniums) and their microwave loss characteristics directly impact qubit coherence times.

This is directly relevant to superconducting circuit quantum electrodynamics and circuit QED research.

The post discusses Josephson junctions, transmon and fluxonium qubit architectures, coherence times, and fabrication processes including aluminum junctions and tantalum ground planes.

summary: This blog post contains one paper directly relevant to superconducting circuits and qubits. The paper 'Highly stable aluminum air-bridges with stiffeners' (Bolgar2025) addresses a critical fabrication challenge in superconducting circuit quantum computing - building stable air-bridge crossovers. Air-bridges are essential components in superconducting qubit circuits for routing signals across different layers without introducing parasitic capacitance or compromising coherence. The blog post explicitly mentions this is for 'superconducting circuit quantum computing folks.' The post also mentions SNSPDs (superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors), but these are photon detection devices rather than qubit circuits, so they are not included.

papers.title: High quality superconducting tantalum resonators with beta phase defects
papers.relevance: Directly about superconducting resonators, which are core components in superconducting qubit circuits and cQED architectures

summary: Found one paper directly related to superconducting circuits: a study on superconducting tantalum resonators. Superconducting resonators are fundamental components in circuit quantum electrodynamics (cQED) and are used for qubit readout, coupling, and quantum memory applications. The paper discusses beta phase defects in these resonators, which is relevant to understanding and improving qubit coherence times.

papers.title: Josephson traveling-wave parametric amplifier based on low-intrinsic-loss coplanar lumped-element waveguide
papers.relevance: Directly about superconducting circuits - a Josephson traveling-wave parametric amplifier (JTWPA) using Josephson junctions, which is a key component in superconducting qubit readout systems

summary: This blog post contains one paper directly related to superconducting circuits and qubits. The paper describes a Josephson traveling-wave parametric amplifier (JTWPA), which is a critical component used in superconducting qubit systems for quantum-limited amplification of readout signals. The device uses Josephson junctions arranged in a coplanar lumped-element waveguide configuration and operates in the 4-12 GHz range, which is typical for superconducting qubit readout. The post also mentions the use of shadow evaporation for fabricating the Josephson junctions, a standard technique in superconducting qubit fabrication.
